records.content: Welcome to the Kayk Gear Reviews Book.

Sorting through what works and does not with kayak gear can be a confusing, costly, and monumental task. There are a lot of opinions, often based on personal taste and paddling style on the web (some reviews very old or dated) and with your fellow club members, paddlers, and others you connect with while paddling. Many recent reviews for a lot of outdoor gear feature an overview, pluses/minuses, cost and honest reviewing, except they lack evaluations of how products work over longer periods. Often the reviewer has just used the product a few times.
This guide features short, to-the-point reviews of kayak gear, some of it long-term. The guide shows easy to read pros/cons, a summary, and who the item is for, followed by brief specs.

Check out book overview in the intro chapter at the Kayak Reviews 

book.

PROS

CONS

ðŸŸ¢ Reasonably priced

ðŸŸ¡ Zippers arenâ€™t saltwater proof

ðŸŸ¢ Durable

ðŸŸ¡ Sizing may run large for some

ðŸŸ¢ Good traction in sole

Every kayaker needs wetsuit boots, especially paddling in colder conditions, which is pretty much all the time! The Lomo wetsuit boots are tough, warm, and very reasonably priced compared to other similar boots. My only gripe about them is the zippers can freeze, even if rinsing after every use (make sure to always store them with zippers zipped) and the sizing may run a bit large. This is a bonus, however for fitting over drysuit booties and when wearing extra layers in winters.

Comfortable and water tight cag that breathes well and moves with you while paddling. The neck and wrist seals are comfortable and keep water out even during capsizes and rolling. It has some nice touches like a chammy patch when you close the hood and ample pockets. The lower pockets have a hand warmer but arenâ€™t accessible when wearing a buoyancy aid. The upper pockets are great but donâ€™t open easily on the water. None of the pockets keep water out.

Although the jacket breathes well, I find that sometimes it feels a bit cold. This isnâ€™t clamminess from sweat building inside nor does the jacket have insulation. Perhaps itâ€™s more breathable fabric and wind compared to other jackets I have that

This helmet just looks cool, plus you get a visor to keep the sun out. Iâ€™m not sure whether to start singing Kissâ€™s Strutter or Sweetâ€™s Ballroom Blitz when I put this helmet on but it does make you want to go out and surf some waves, run a tiderace, or negotiate splosh. Altho, generally pricey can often get them on sale. At the time of publishing Escape Watersports had a neon green Strutter for sale at Â£49.99. As mentioned, in the cons, I found the headband to be uncomfortable at first after about 1 hr of paddling. This has gradually subsided and Iâ€™m not sure whether I broke in the helmet or it broke me.
Anyone going rockhopping, into waves or more advanced conditionsl

PROS

CONS

ðŸŸ¢ Durable

ðŸŸ¡ Neck gasket very tight

ðŸŸ¢ Priced right

ðŸŸ¡ Shoulder zipper hard to zip

ðŸŸ¢ Doesnâ€™t leak (especially the neck!)

ðŸŸ¡ Zipper flap is flappy

I was super jealous of kayakers with hoods when I first bought this suit and realized it was made more for river kayakers. But I soon realized that having a hood in wind blows and you never use the hoods anyway so itâ€™s awesome. The suit is duper durable with cordura in hard wearing areas. I found the latex neck seal to be very tight and had to cut several notches down to fit me (and I have a pretty skinny neck). It was so tight it felt like someone was choking me and I dreaded putting it on. Once I trimmed it, it was fine. Besides the neck the suit fits well. I found the shoulder zipper to be difficult to reach and close, but that became much easier with a few applications of ti-zip to lube it. The flap over the zipper also gets stuck up or the wind blows it up. Seems like this could be removed, or fixed down with some double sided velcro.

This suit doesnâ€™t breath as well as more expensive suits, but if you layer right, you can avoid excessive moisture build up on the inside. It dries very fast, even the booties. Iâ€™ve had mine for 3 years and the only sign of wear is in the â€˜socksâ€™ and I had to sew and patch the neoprene in the neck after it tore. Really good value for money, especially for your first suit when youâ€™re trying things out and donâ€™t want to spend a ton on new kit.
Entry level kayakers that need a drysuit but donâ€™t want to spend >Â£600 to get going.

Different colors, deck out your boat with rad colored hatches.

Anyone that wants to or needs to replace the hatches that came with their boat. These are a much improved version, for instance of the NDK hatch covers. I have three that Iâ€™ve fitted on NDK and P&H boats. Steve Whetman first mentioned theyâ€™re designed for fiberglass boats, but Iâ€™ve found they work on plastic boats as well. They work! What more can you say.

ðŸŸ¢ Moderate size fits on deck

ðŸŸ¡ Pump handle broke after 3 years use

ðŸŸ¢ Pumps well & > than small pumps

ðŸŸ¡ Floaty foam is deteriorating

ðŸŸ¢

ðŸŸ¡

I really liked this pump until I was pumping out my cockpit following an exercise rescue in F5 winds and 2m swell. It still pumped and Iâ€™ve since taped it up, but makes me wonder what else might break when I really need it. Other than that questionable durability, this pump works well, with high volume water compared to smaller bilge pumps. The floaty foam circle on it is deteriorating but saltwater and sun exposure has a tendency to degrade material like this over time. None of the metal has rusted, a big plus, and something on other â€˜seaworthyâ€™ gear that you would think would be required.
Everyone needs a pump for rescues, general leakage and every single time you land for lunch and your cockpit has taken on more than a few spongeful (spongefulls?) of water.

Cost: Â£19.95

Weight:

URL: 

https://â€‹wwwâ€‹.nrseuropeâ€‹.comâ€‹/productâ€‹/50033â€‹.02â€‹/nrsâ€‹-kayakâ€‹-bilgeâ€‹-pump

Review date: 15 October, 2025

PROS

CONS

ðŸŸ¢ Exceptionally stable in all conditions

ðŸŸ¡ Cockpit too short

ðŸŸ¢ Tracks nicely

ðŸŸ¡ Skeg sticking (who needs skegs?)

ðŸŸ¢ Spartan outfitting means little can break

ðŸŸ¡ A bit slow picking up waves/surf

ðŸŸ¢ Indestructible

ðŸŸ¡ Seat can be harsh on longer paddles

Full disclosure: I purchased this boat used so itâ€™s features and design may have been updated in newer models. The age of this boat, however is testimony to its durability.

Hatches
Skeg
Cockpit bolts ripping clothing and trap hazard
Hard line on cockpit sraping shins. again had to tap over this. filing might even be a better solution
Not really sure why the cockpit rim is fibreglass rather than moulded, which would be smoother. That supposedly reduces weight and makes it stiff, but it means that you scrape body parts on it. In my boat the rim is attached with bolt that are raw on the inside and have ripped clothing when exiting the boat and even momentarily trapped me during rescue exercises. Iâ€™ve taped over these to avoid that in the future, but itâ€™s something to be aware of and certainly something the manufacturer should fix, e.g., cut off ends or put caps on them.

Could really use some actual knee braces, hip pads, and an adjustable back brace.

NDK says â€˜The kayak has been designed to fit a range of kayakers from approx. 5ft 4inch (162 cm) to 6ft 4inches (193 cm) tall & there is plenty of room for large feet.â€™ Thereâ€™s no way someone 193 cms could easily get their legs in and out of this boat. Iâ€™m 6â€™1" and always scrape my knees getting out.
Beginner to intermediate (short, e.g., <175 cm) paddler who likes rockhopping, waves, and smooth to rough water conditions.

Great fitting jacket for long distance paddles (

FigureÂ 1)

Bladder pocket is for Astral bladders that donâ€™t seem to exist. It isnâ€™t a pocket anyway, since itâ€™s on the inside of the vest and would be uncomfortable if a bladder was fitted in the tiny place.

The pockets at the waist are inaccessible during paddling. The hand warmer pocket is useful, but the neoprene-ish material at the bottom gets wet and stays wet somewhat negating the warming function and making the jacket difficult to dry after use.

The clamshell pockets at the front is awesome and easily accessible as well as being useful for a â€˜trayâ€™ while sorting through kit. It is too small, however and Iâ€™m unable to fit much in the pocket other than knife, camera, ouch pouch, whistle, and compass. Even then itâ€™s bulging

A smaller strap on the shoulder strap for attaching a radio or emergency GPS beacon broke after about 18 months of use. Fortunately it has a sturdier plastic backing.

Review date: DD Month Year

The Kayak Gear Review Book features short- and long-term kayak gear reviews for beginners and seasoned veterans alike. All reviews are of kit that either I have or guest authors have purchased and used, preferably over several years of use.

Each chapter is organized with a pros cons table, for example:

PROS

CONS

ðŸŸ¢ Excellent comfort

ðŸŸ¡ Fit may not work for some

ðŸŸ¢ Waterproof & breathable construction

ðŸŸ¡ Expensive price point

ðŸŸ¢ Great in varied temperatures and conditions

ðŸŸ¡ Hood blows off in windy conditions

The table is followed by a summary overview of the gearâ€™s performance, who the gear is for, and brief specs including cost at time of review, weight from my scales, and a url to the manufacturer or place to purchase the item.

The book is organized into broad categorical chapters featuring equipment we have tried in each category. It isnâ€™t an exhaustive list, rather itâ€™s meant to feature commonly used or needed items and items that we have actually worn on numerous trips from flatwater to tideraces and other advanced conditions. The chapters are organized in the following manner:

Clothing. Performance clothing kayakers wear on the water.

Extras. Other necessary pieces of kit, e.g., pump.

Kayaks. Reviews of the kayaks most often purchased by beginner to advanced paddlers.

Paddles. Paddle reviews. There are millions of paddles out there, how do you choose the right one? These will help (and hopefully help you avoid spend loads Â£Â£Â£s on a paddle you donâ€™t like).

Safety gear. Essential safety gear and reviews of gear that worked, bt not as well as current kit.

Review contributions are welcome! Please feel free to reach out and offer kit reviews. The easiest way to do this is to visit the github 

repo, download one of the chapter markdown files, write the review then make a pull request.
